I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2007  Country  Programming  Mission  for  the  People’s  Republic  of  China 
(PRC), the Government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide a technical 
assistance1 (TA) to support the Government’s preparation of the proposed Jiangxi Sustainable 
Forest Ecosystem Development Project (the Project) for ADB financing. 
 
2.  ADB fielded reconnaissance and fact-finding missions in April 2008 and July 2008, 
respectively. The missions met with national and provincial officials, and other key stakeholders; 
and reached agreement on the TA output, outcome, implementation arrangements, cost and 
financing plan, and terms of reference of the consultants. The TA concept paper was approved 
on 25 July 2008. This TA paper has been prepared based on the understandings reached 
between  ADB  missions  and  the  Government,  and  comments  received  during  ADB’s 
interdepartmental review.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The Government’s 11th Five-Year Plan (FYP, 2006–2010) emphasizes the need to build a 
harmonious  and  moderately  prosperous  society  which  will  be  resource-efficient  and 
environment-friendly. ADB’s Country Partnership Strategy 2008–2010 (CPS)2 and Long-Term 
Strategic Framework 2008–2020 “Strategy 2020”3 support measures aimed at promoting the 
sustainable management of forests to better adapt to the challenges of a broad range of 
environmental issues such as climate change. Forests play a critical role in influencing the 
Earth’s climate. Forest plants and soils drive the global carbon cycle by sequestering carbon 
dioxide through photosynthesis and releasing it through respiration. It is estimated that forest 
and land-use measures have the potential to reduce the global net carbon emissions by the 
equivalent of 10–20% of projected fossil fuel emissions through 2050. Research in the PRC has 
shown that one hectare (ha) of forest could store 245.6 tons of water, preserve 67.8 tons of 
fertilizer, and reduce soil erosion by 33.9 tons. It was also estimated that the carbon storage 
capacity of forests could be as high as 70 tons/ha. 
 
4.  The PRC has been a forest-deficit country despite its forest cover of about 175 million ha 
and a standing timber stock of about 12.5 billion cubic meters (m3). While the PRC’s forest 
cover  has  increased  to  18.2%  of  the  total  land  area  in  2006  due  to  extensive  plantation 
programs since the early 1980s, the PRC’s per capita forested area is only 0.13 ha, far below 
the world average of 0.65 ha. The standing stock volume amounts to less than 10 m3 per capita, 
which is also significantly lower than the world average of 66 m3. The Government has adopted 
a  series  of  reforms  in  forestry  policies  since  the  1980s  to  address  the  issues  of  timber 
production, forest resources conservation, and ecosystem restoration. These forestry policies 
and reforms include the amendment of the Forest Law of 1998, the Natural Forest Protection 
Program of 1998, the Six National Key Forest Programs of 2000, and the Forest Land Reform of 
2007. Such policies and reforms reflect a shift of forestry policy from resource exploitation to 
resource protection and have helped the PRC to successfully increase its forest area and timber 
stock over the last 2 decades. The rapid economic growth has escalated the country’s demand 
for wood fiber and forest products which oftentimes have to be imported from abroad, especially 
from the neighboring Southeast Asian countries.

5.  Jiangxi is an underdeveloped mountainous province with a total area of 16.69 million ha. 
The provincial gross domestic product (GDP) was only CNY467 billion in 2006, about 2.2% of 
the national GDP; per capita GDP of CNY10,000, which is about 62% of the national average; 
and rural per capita net income of CNY3,585, which is about 22% of the national average. 
About 5% of the population still live below the poverty line of $1/day, of whom most are 
peasants living in the mountainous areas. In 2001, approximately 64% or 10.63 million ha of the 
land was designated as forest land, of which one third was classified as national or provincial 
public welfare forest lands for strict protection and conservation. The province is within the 
fourth  forest  region  according  to  the  State  Forestry  Administration’s  classification  in  2005, 
meaning the provincial government is required to improve the quality and quantity of forest 
management,  and  enhance  the  protection  of  the  ecological  environment.  Due  to  the  low 
provincial GDP, the Jiangxi Provincial Government (JPG) has not been able to secure sufficient 
financial resources to meet the investment needs for forestry development. 
 
6.  Jiangxi Province lies in the eastern part of the PRC to the south of the middle-lower 
reach of the Yangtze River. The area has a warm and humid climate with plentiful rain and 
sunshine year round. The average annual temperature is around 16.3oC –19.5oC, and the mean 
annual  precipitation  is  1,351–1,934  millimeters.  The  soil  in  the  province  is  mostly  40–100 
centimeters (cm) thick with a humus layer of 8–20 cm. The mild weather and fertile soil provide 
an environment suitable for tree growth and forest development. Jiangxi Province’s forested 
area ranks second in the country. However, the development of forest resources is stagnant 
mainly due to (i) historical overexploitation of forest resources that has deteriorated the forest 
structure and quality,4 and (ii) lack of sufficient funding for forest development. Fifteen percent or 
1.6 million ha of the forest lands are under open forest lands, shrublands, and barren mountains 
which are low-yielding and underutilized. The high percentage of underutilized forest lands in 
the province is not only a waste of land resources but also causes serious environmental 
problems such as soil erosion, siltation, and flooding to the downstream Boyang Hu Lake and 
Yangtze River. The devastating flood in the Yangtze River in 1998 caused the Government to 
shift its forestry policy from resource exploitation to resource protection to reverse soil erosion 
and minimize other environmental problems in watershed management.  
 
7.  JPG launched its Forest Land Tenure Reform in 2004 and distributed 13.448 million mu5  
of collective forest lands to 6.916 million farm households who acquired management rights of 
the forest lands. The Forest Land Tenure Reform helped privatize and commercialize forestry 
development in the Jiangxi Province. This has accelerated the development of forestry sector in 
the province and improved rural livelihoods. As a result, the total forest area was 3.524 million 
mu in 2006, the highest over the past 10 years, of which private sector plantations including 
enterprises and individual farms planted 2.637 million mu. Further in 2006, JPG issued a 
provincial order to develop “Six Systems and One Center” to strengthen the land tenure reform 
including  a  forestry  resources  management  system;  a  forestry  industry  system;  a  forestry 
investment and financing system; a forestry science and technology service system; a forestry 
policy, strategy, and regulation system; a forestry insurance system; and a forestry property 
right  trade  center  system.  Fifty  county  forestry  trade  and  information  centers  have  been 
established since then. These centers provide services on forest land tenure and property 
registration, information disclosure, legal consultation, and forestry property and product trading. 
Such services facilitate the participation of the private sector and help develop an open, fair, and 
transparent market for forest land tenure and product trading at the county and provincial levels.  
 
                                                 
4  The composition of tree species and live stand age are below standards, and the capacity of forest management is 
yet to be improved. The average crown density of stands is less than 50%; and the forest stock volume per unit 
area is only 44.5% of the national average, ranking 19th in the country. 
5  1 mu = 1/15 hectare.

3
8.  According to provincial statistics, there were 5,793 wood processing enterprises in 2006, 
of which 32 were listed as provincial leading enterprises involved in wood, bamboo, camellia oil 
processing, forestation, and tea, fruit, and medicinal herb processing. About 4.6 million m3 of 
forestry products were produced including timber, fuel wood, and bamboo. The total value of 
forest outputs was CNY48 billion. It was estimated that the capacity of the timber processing 
industry would reach about 5 million m3, and the annual forestry product consumption of 7.64 
million m3 by 2008. To meet the consumption demand for forestry products, JPG has to import 
forest products from outside of the province; and accelerate public and private investments in 
forestry industry in the province.  
 
9.  It is JPG’s long-term goal to achieve a forest coverage of 63%, forest stock volume of 
750 million m3, average forestry production of 90 m3/ha, and total forestry output of CNY160 
billion by 2020. To accomplish these goals, JPG will need to plant 12 million mu of commercial 
forest, 9 million mu of Moso bamboo forest, and 5 million mu of camellia oil plantation during its 
11th FYP period (2006–2010).   
 
10.  JPG has been receiving financial support to improve forest plantation, research and 
studies, capacity building, and environmental management since the 1990s. The World Bank 
provided around $64 million during 1990–2005 to assist in the implementation of the National 
Afforestation Program, the Forestry Resources Development and Protection Program, and the 
Forestry Development in Poor Areas. The World Bank projects helped develop 191,400 ha of 
forest lands in 69 counties.  Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau provided €8.69 million during 1998–
2003 to assist six counties in forestation of 37,033 ha of forest lands. The Japan Bank for 
International  Cooperation6 provides  approximately  $60  million  during  2004–2009  for  forest 
plantations development on 219,203 ha and institution building in 36 counties.  
 
11.  A recent evaluation report7 on forest conservation programs in the PRC pointed out that 
forestry programs with major environmental objectives had to consider poverty and livelihoods 
simultaneously.  Lessons  learned  from  an  ADB  forest  project  in  the  PRC8 showed  that 
comprehensive  capacity  development  was  important  to  ensure  long-term  economic  and 
financial viability of the pulp mill enterprise. Another evaluation report9 further suggested that 
successful  poverty  reduction  interventions  linked  the  poor  to  economic  growth  centers, 
commercial value-adding enterprises, and associated off-farm employment opportunities. ADB’s 
experiences with forestry projects10 indicated that local ownership and understanding of local 
forest knowledge and practices were critical to the success of introducing new techniques on 
timber harvesting and reforestation. The World Bank’s evaluation report11 concluded that the 
PRC’s forest work and management had been remarkably successful mainly due to the high 
priority accorded by the Government to forestry sector development and a high level of project 
ownership including staff capacity, and adequate and timely provision of budgetary resources.   
 
12.  The external support from various development partners has enhanced the techniques 
of reforestation and improved the knowledge of forestry management in the Jiangxi provincial

and participating county governments. JPG is yet to achieve its goal of forestry development set 
out in the 11th FYP which requires the Government to invest more than CNY4 billion and provide 
technical support to local governments for reforestation and forest management. JPG is, thus, 
requesting ADB to provide financing and technical assistance, in addition to the support from 
other international financing agencies, to continue its efforts in sustainable forest development 
and facilitate private sector participation in the forestry industry.  
 
13.  A devastating snow storm hit the province in January 2008 which worsened JPG’s fiscal 
capacity in meeting the investment needs of the forestry sector. The snow storm affected about 
53.5 million mu of forest lands including shelter forests, timber forests, and bamboo forests; and 
caused a direct economic loss of CNY1,126 billion. Many natural reserves and scenic spots 
were also severely damaged. Over 4 million mu of forest land will need to be reforested, and the 
forest ecosystem needs to be restored. The snow storm incident reveals some hidden issues of 
forest management in Jiangxi, which are (i) the lack of sustainable forest product supply in the 
province due to weak forest management strategies, and (ii) the lack of state-of-art forest 
management practices to protect forest resources from natural disastrous damages, such as 
climate change adaptation and forest insurance mechanism. Due to the lack of clear policy and 
strategies on forest insurance, public awareness, and adequate expertise in the province, the 
insurance mechanism is yet to be developed. 
 
14.   The proposed sustainable forest ecosystem development project will (i) improve forest 
plantation  and  forest  resources  management  by  introducing  practices  of  climate  change 
adaptation to the project area to ensure the sustainability of forest yields in the province, which 
will also alleviate pressure on neighboring countries’ forest resources in the region, and (ii) 
introducing  a  proper  forest  insurance  system  to  minimize  disastrous  damages  to  forest 
resources. The TA and the ensuing investment project are in line with ADB’s Forest Policy 
(1995), 12  and  the  core  areas  of  operations  in  ADB’s  Strategy  2020,  which  includes 
environmental  measures  such  as  arresting  deforestation  and  sustainable  management  of 
forests to address climate change. The amount of the ensuing loan is estimated as $40 million 
which is included in the 2010 assistance program of the ADB’s CPS.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
15.   The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  improved  forest  management  and  environmental 
sustainability in the Jiangxi Province. The TA outcome will be a project design suitable for ADB 
financing  and  agreed  upon  by  the  Government  and  ADB.  The  TA  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. The initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  A  participatory  approach  will  be  adopted  during  the  TA  implementation  to  solicit 
stakeholders’ views and suggestions on the project design and implementation mechanism. A 
total of 24 counties have indicated interest in participating in the Project. Consultants will be 
engaged to (i) identify sector issues with manageable solution, and explore opportunities for 
promoting low-carbon growth and private sector participation in forest development; (ii) evaluate 
the rationale and justifications of the proposed investment activities; (iii) prepare safeguard 
documents and a knowledge product on forest land rehabilitation to facilitate policy dialogue; (iv) 
set up a geographic information system (GIS) for use in selected counties; (v) conduct training

to  strengthen  the  institutional  capacity  in  project  implementation  and  natural  disaster  risk 
management; (vi) prepare an investment plan with acceptable implementation arrangements; 
and  (vii)  submit  periodic  reports  prior  to  each  tripartite  review.  An  overseas  training  on 
sustainable forest management and climate change adaptation will be conducted in an Asia 
Pacific region country for a maximum of five people from JPG. The Project will also explore the 
possibility of cofinancing with the Global Environment Facility or ADB’s Climate Change Fund to 
support climate change adaptation and mitigation.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The  total  TA  cost  is  estimated  at  $826,000  equivalent,  of  which  $700,000  will  be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. Detailed cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 3. The PRC Government will finance the remaining $126,000 equivalent in 
local currency through in-kind contributions. The Government has been informed that approval 
of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  JPG will establish a TA leading group, which will be chaired by the Vice Governor in 
charge of forestry, and will comprise high level officials from the Departments of Forestry and 
Finance, and the Provincial Development and Reform Commission. The leading group will 
provide overall policy and strategic guidance during TA implementation. The Department of 
Forestry will be the executing agency, and responsible for TA implementation. Specifically, the 
executing  agency  will  (i)  prepare  a  feasibility  study  report  and  environmental  report  in 
compliance with the Government’s requirements, (ii) oversee the preparation of the investment 
plan, (iii) coordinate TA activities of participating counties, (iv) assist TA consultants to secure all 
the reports and data needed for TA implementation, and (v) secure all the necessary internal 
approvals  for  the  feasibility  study  report  and  related  documents.  The  participating  county 
governments  will  be  the  implementing  agencies  and  will  be  responsible  for  (i)  conducting 
stakeholder consultations and assisting in social surveys, (ii) providing baseline data of the 
county subprojects, and (iii) providing comments on the project design. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 7 months, from February to September 2009. The TA 
will require approximately 42 person-months of consulting services including 13 person-months 
of international consulting services and 29 person-months of national consulting services. The 
outline terms of reference for consulting services is in Appendix 4. A consulting firm will be 
selected according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). The quality- and cost-based selection procedure (with quality-cost ratio of 80:20) 
will be applied based on biodata technical proposal. Two resource persons may be recruited by 
ADB using single source selection to conduct special studies and training on climate change 
adaptation and the use of GIS in sustainable forest management. Equipment will be procured 
following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). The consulting 
firm will submit an inception report, an interim report, and a draft final report within the first, 
fourth, and sixth months, respectively. A final report will be submitted within the seventh month 
after incorporating the Government’s and ADB’s comments.  
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Preparing the Jiangxi Sustainable Forest 
Ecosystem Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy, and the sector analysis, describe 
how the Project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction; and how it is linked to the poverty reduction 
strategy of the partner country. 
 
The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)’s  11th  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010)  prioritizes 
environmentally sustainable and inclusive rural development through the New Socialist Countryside Policy. To support 
the PRC Government achieve its goals, the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Country Partnership Strategy for the 
PRC (2008–2010) sets out its key priorities which include (i) enhanced inclusiveness through balanced development 
with a focus on rural and poorer regions, and (ii) environmental sustainability through more effective natural resources 
management. The PRC has achieved remarkable results in overall poverty reduction over the last three decades but 
significant pockets of poverty persist. Nationally, poor people mostly live in the central and western provinces that lag 
behind the eastern provinces in achieving the Millennium Development Goals. In these regions, poor people live mainly 
in remote rural areas where poverty is strongly correlated to the degradation of natural resources.  
 
Jiangxi is an underdeveloped mountainous province. The provincial gross domestic product (GDP) was only CNY467 
billion, which is about 2.2% of the national GDP, and the GDP per capita just reached CNY10,000 in 2006, which is 
about 62% of the national average. The per capita annual net income of rural residents was only CNY3,585; only 22% 
of the national average. Approximately 5% of the population still lives below the poverty line of $1/day. Most of the poor 
are farmers living in the mountainous areas. The Project, thus, aims to improve forest management efficiency including 
increase of forest yield, forest cover, and farmers’ income by (i) introducing short cycle commercial forests, (ii) 
improving low-yield Moso bamboo forests, (iii) introducing high-value economic forests, and (iv) capacity building on 
sustainable forest management. This will result in balanced development whereby rural farmers increase their income 
through lease of their forest land or sales of raw materials while ensuring environmental sustainability.  
 
B.  Targeting Classification          
1.  Select the targeting classification of the Project: 
 General Intervention (GI)     Individual or Household (TI-H)   
 Geographic (TI-G)       Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
 
2.  Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
As described above, about 5% of the total population in the Jiangxi Province still lives below the poverty line of $1 per 
day, most of whom are farmers living in the mountainous areas. The Project aims to benefit these people by investing 
in sustainable forestry which is the primary industry for these people. However, given the complexity of the forestry 
industry, need for sufficient forest land, and need to secure market accessibility, management cannot only target the 
poor but must involve a variety of stakeholders such as forest management enterprises, state-owned forest farms, and 
other public forest farms. The Project is, therefore, classified as a general intervention. 
  
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
  Not applicable    
2.  What resources are allocated in the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA)/due diligence?                   
  Not applicable 
3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross-subsidy, pro-
poor governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
A key design feature builds on the findings of a recent ADB evaluation of poverty exit achievements which highlighted 
the success from linking the rural poor to commercial value-adding enterprises. The Project applies this through 
supporting  forest  management  enterprises,  state-owned  forest  farms,  other  public  forest  farms,  and  farmer 
associations located in the project area; and applying poverty-targeting criteria to extend assistance to the poorer 
farmers.

II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
 
Based on existing information: 
 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit 
from the project? 
 
Primary beneficiaries are the communities, primarily poor, who use the natural resources from the mountains for their 
living. Of the total forest lands, 85% is managed jointly or individually by the farmers. Based on the profit-sharing ratio 
between the land users and forest land owner, they are expected to receive 35% of the total benefits. Additional 
income is likely to be gained through provision of services to enterprises and farms. The process and the outcome of 
the Project will benefit the poor in several ways. First, inclusive participatory approach will be adopted in the project 
design process. This provides the poor people opportunities to provide inputs into critical decision making for natural 
resource management that has direct impact on their livelihoods. Local government officials and consultants will 
monitor and ensure the quality of participation. Second, more managed use of natural resources minimizes their social 
vulnerability. And finally, improving the cooperation between farmers and forest farms, forest management enterprises, 
and farmer associations would give farmers better access to market, thus, increasing their income.   
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
The Project entails two new activities for the local communities–introduction of fast-growing forestation for raw 
materials and high-value economic forest. As farmers may not be fully familiar with the necessary technical skills, they 
will need a significant amount of capacity building.  If they are to enter into partnership with forest farms or manage the 
resources collectively, they will also need to be provided with marketing, accounting, and negotiation skills training.  
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project 
address them? 
 
One potential constraint is that collaboration between farmers and forest farms or enterprises may not work as well as 
expected. In order to address this issue, the project design will include opportunities for public participation and conduct 
a thorough consultation with all stakeholders. Moreover, the government will establish a course of redress and dispute 
resolution mechanism where farmers (or the enterprises and farms) can channel their complaints. 
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
 
1.  Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
 
Farmers, community members utilizing the land or natural resources in the forest land, farmer associations, forest 
farms, forest enterprises, and staff of executing agency and implementing agencies.  
 
2.  What  type  of  consultation  and  participation  is  required  during  the  PPTA  or  project  processing  (e.g., 
workshops,  community  mobilization,  involvement  of  nongovernment  organizations  and  community-based 
organizations, etc.)? 
 
Community members, farmer associations, farms, and enterprises will be consulted in identifying their needs and views 
on the Project which will then be reflected on the design. 
  
3.  What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
 Information sharing     Consultation   Collaborative decision making   Empowerment 
 
4.  Will a consultation and participation plan be prepared?   Yes   No  Please explain.  
 
Farmers and community consultation and participation is critical to ensure the project sustainability. A consultation and 
participation plan will be prepared.

10  Appendix 2 
 
 
C.  Gender and Development 
 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector and/or subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project or 
program? 
 
Based on existing information provided by the Jiangxi provincial government and others, there seem to be no project-
specific gender issues. The Project may be confronted with generic gender issues in the rural PRC, not specific to the 
sector or subsector. This could be insufficient participation of women in community decision-making process or limited 
access to employment opportunities and income, both exacerbating their social vulnerability.  
 
2.  Does the proposed project or program have the potential to promote gender equality and/or women’s 
empowerment by improving women’s access to and use of opportunities, services, resources, assets, and participation 
in decision making?    Yes   No  Please explain.  
 
The Project could increase women’s participation in decision-making regarding natural resources management and 
improve their access to income through contracts with farmers or enterprises. However, the Project intends to provide 
benefits on a household basis rather than on specific members of the households.  
 
3.  Could the proposed Project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or widen gender inequality? 
     Yes   No  Please explain.  
 
The Project will be implemented in a community participatory manner where views of different stakeholders will be 
reflected in the project design to the extent possible. It is the project policy to fully engage the women in the project 
design. Therefore, no adverse impact will emanate from the Project.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services 
 
1.   The technical assistance (TA) will assist the Department of Forestry, the executing 
agency (EA), Jiangxi provincial government (JPG) in preparing the Jiangxi Sustainable Forest 
Ecosystem Development Project (the Project). About 24 counties will participate in the Project, 
of which six are national poverty counties. The counties were selected based on the following 
criteria: (i) project implementation capacity and adequate sizes and sites of land resources, (ii) 
capability of repayment and commitment to providing counterpart funds, and (iii) capability of 
adopting a bottom-up decision-making process to ensure community and voluntary participation. 
The  following  terms  of  reference  and  person-month  requirements  are  only  indicative.  The 
consulting firm is encouraged to make the most cost-effective arrangement for its manning 
schedule to achieve the best results.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
2.  The TA will require a total of 42 person-months of consulting services including 13 
person-months of international consultants and 29 person-months of national consultants. The 
international consultants will include a forestry economist/team leader, a forest environment 
specialist,  and  an  agricultural  insurance  specialist.  The  national  consultants  will  include  a 
forestry economist/deputy team leader, a financial specialist, a forest plantation specialist, an 
agricultural insurance specialist, a geographic information system (GIS) specialist, a social 
development specialist, and a forest ecosystem specialist. A full-time interpreter of 6 person-
months, with proficiency in verbal and written Chinese-English translation, will be hired to assist 
the communication between the Consultant and EA, and the translation of important key reports 
from Chinese to English and vice versa. The TA is expected to be completed in 7 months. 
 
1.  Forestry Economist/Team Leader (international, 6 person-months)   
 
3.  TA Implementation Management. The international forestry economist/team leader, 
with the assistance of the deputy team leader, will be responsible for the preparation and 
delivery of all reports, supervision of the Consultant’s work progress, and ensuring the quality 
and timely delivery of the team’s outputs. The team leader shall be responsible for the following 
administration activities: 
(i)  Prepare a detailed work plan for the team which shall include elaborated tasks 
and outputs for both the international and national consultants, and a schedule 
for submissions of various reports and conduct of review workshops and monitor 
their implementation. 
(ii)  Formulate  the  overall  project  design,  define  its  scope  and  implementation 
arrangements, estimate costs, and prepare project reports including the project 
feasibility study report suitable for appraisal by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and the Government. 
(iii)  Coordinate with EA in preparing for the review workshops and conducting one 
training workshop on project implementation and management, and assist EA in 
organizing a study tour on sustainable forest ecosystem management.  
 (iv)  Prepare  a  technical  note  on  best  practices  and  policy  notes  on  forest  land 
rehabilitation and climate change adaptation as a knowledge product of the TA to 
facilitate potential policy dialogue with high-level decision makers.

14     Appendix 4 
 
4.  Sector and Economic Analyses. The consultant will conduct an economic analysis in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects (1997), Handbook for 
Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects (2001), Poverty 
Analysis Handbook (2007), and Handbook on Social Analysis (2007). The economic analysis 
will include, but not be limited, to the following task: 
(i)   Confirm the project components with EA. Review the project rationale based on a 
problem analysis and provide a basis for ADB involvement. Assess the relevance 
and priority of the Project to the Government’s forestry sector strategy and ADB’s 
Country Partnership Strategy for the People’s Republic of China (PRC).1 
(ii)        Conduct demand analysis together with the financial specialist. 
(iii)   Conduct alternative analysis to identify the least-cost solution and a distribution 
analysis,  including  poverty  impact,  to  identify  the  winners  and  losers  of  the 
Project. 
(iv)   Identify all project economic costs and benefits comparing with- and without-
project situations.  In addition to converting financial flows into economic flows, 
the  economic  costs  and  benefits  will  also  include  environmental  costs  and 
benefits. Estimate the economic internal rate of return on the basis of non-
incremental and incremental economic benefits and economic costs in constant 
economic prices. 
 (v)  Undertake a sensitivity analysis to assess the effects of adverse changes in key 
assumptions that underline the economic analysis including, but not limited to, 
project costs and implementation delays. If the Project is sensitive to the value of 
a key variable, recommend measures to minimize the risk.  
(vi)  Carry out a quantitative risk analysis in accordance with ADB’s Handbook for 
Integrating Risk Analysis in the Economic Analysis of Projects (2002). 
(vii)  Develop for project monitoring a set of verifiable performance indicators including 
financial,  environmental,  socioeconomic,  and  poverty  reduction  parameters. 
Specify baseline targets for the socioeconomic and poverty indicators, and a 
sustainable mechanism for monitoring during and beyond the plantation stage. 
(viii)  Assess  the  developmental  impact  of  the  Project  and  draw  up  a  project 
performance management system. 
 
5.  Institutional  Strengthening  and  Implementation  Arrangements.  The  forestry 
economists will work with the consultant team to conduct following tasks: 
(i)    Review current institutional structure of forest management in the province and 
participating counties, and the implementation arrangements for the Project; and 
identify  training  needs  to  strengthen  the  institutional  capacity  of  project 
implementation. 
(ii)   Prepare a capacity building plan and training materials; identify trainees and 
resource persons, when needed; and conduct the training and a post-training 
evaluation to assess its effectiveness. 
 
2.  Forestry Economist/Deputy Team Leader (national, 6 person-months) 
 
6.  Sector  and  Economic  Analyses  and  TA  Implementation  Management.  The 
consultant will assist the team leader in completing the sector and economic analysis, and help 
the training and TA implementation management. 
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China (2008–2010). Manila.

Appendix 4     15 
7.  Agricultural Insurance Mechanism. The national forestry economist will also assist in 
the following assessment work for the development of the agricultural insurance mechanism: 
(i)  Work  closely  with  the  agricultural  insurance  specialists  on  the  options  for 
agriculture insurance in the project area. 
(ii)  Identify financial discrepancies between the affordable premium level and the 
cost of providing insurance in the project area; and estimate the government 
subsidies, if needed, for the proposed insurance. 
(iii)  Assess the provincial and local governments’ fiscal and institutional capacity to 
implement the proposed agricultural insurance mechanism. 
(iv)  Compare the government subsidies required for the insurance with the historical 
economic  loss  due  to  disaster  and  the  disaster  relief  mobilized  by  the 
Government to assess the fiscal desirability of the proposed insurance from the 
Government’s perspective. 
 
3.  Financial Specialist (national, 5 person-months) 
 
8.  The financial analysis of the Project should be carried out in accordance with ADB’s 
Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005),including a financial return at constant 
 
prices and financial projections over 10 years at current prices. The tasks of the financial 
specialist shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(i)      Calculate the financial internal rate of return and the weighted average cost of 
capital  for  comparison  with  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return.  Conduct  a 
sensitivity analysis including the effects of a change in the exchange rate.  
(ii)  Undertake a sustainability analysis and cost recovery mechanism looking at both 
the financial implications and implementation capacity. 
(iii)  Undertake financial due diligence for the participating enterprises and farmers, 
prepare  criteria  for  selecting  financially  viable  enterprises,  and  assess  the 
financial management capacity of the EA and/or implementing agencies (IAs) to 
implement the Project.  
(iv)  Review  the  forestation  and  plantation  investment  plan  prepared  by  EA  and 
prepare the cost estimates using ADB’s COSTAB. 
(v)  Conduct a market demand analysis together with the economist. 
(vi)  Based on ADB’s lending terms, prepare a financing plan elaborating financing 
sources  and  percentages,  and  a  fund  channeling  mechanism  and 
implementation arrangements for the Project. 
 
4.  Forest Environment/Ecosystem Specialists (international, 4 person-months; 
national, 4 person-months) 
 
9.  The forest environment/ecosystem specialists will undertake environmental assessment 
tasks and prepare documents for cofinancing by the Global Environment Facility (GEF) or 
ADB’s  Climate  Change  Fund,  if  assessed  eligible.  The  Project  is  tentatively  classified  as 
Environment  Category  B.  The  environment  specialists  will  carry  out  an  environmental 
assessment  based  on  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  (2002)  and  Environmental  Assessment 
Guidelines (2003), and the PRC’s relevant laws and regulations. The environment specialists’ 
work will include, but not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)    Review the environmental examination document prepared by EA to ensure that 
it complies with the Government’s requirements and ADB’s Environment Policy 
and  relevant  requirements,  and  reassess  and  confirm  the  environmental 
categorization of the Project.

16     Appendix 4 
 
(ii)   Collect  secondary  data;  assess  potential  environmental  impacts  and  public 
benefits and economic values of the Project, especially the global environmental 
benefits; and undertake public consultations with stakeholders, as necessary, to 
improve the quality of the environmental document. 
(iii)   Discuss  with  EA  and  prepare  mitigation  measures  and  management  plan, 
especially a soil and water conservation scheme and the associated cost, and 
ensure their incorporation into the project design. 
(iv)   Following ADB’s requirements, assist JPG in preparing an Initial Environmental 
Examination (IEE) and prepare a Summary IEE based on the findings of the 
environmental examination.  
(v)   Review the damages resulting from the snow storms in the project area and 
current  rehabilitation  activities.  Recommend  methodology  and  activities  to 
improve the rehabilitation and the project plantation. Assess the rehabilitation 
goals and activities, estimate the costs of rehabilitation and identify funding gaps, 
and evaluate the eligibility of the rehabilitation work for GEF financing. 
(vi)       Prepare a GEF Project Identification Form and Request for Project Preparation 
Grant for the application of GEF financing, if assessed eligible.  
 
5.   Social Development Specialist (national, 3 person-months) 
 
10.  The social development specialist will complete the following tasks:  
(i)    Prepare socioeconomic and poverty profiles for the project area. Collect data 
through statistical records, field surveys, key informant interviews (e.g., officials 
of local governments,  women’s federation, business associations, community 
groups,  and  others)  and  participatory  community  appraisal  techniques  with 
assistance  from  EA  and  IAs.  Put  emphasis  in  analyzing  the  different  roles, 
responsibilities, skills, and competencies of both male and female community 
members. Data collected by the consultant should, to the extent possible, be 
gender-disaggregate. 
(ii)   Prepare surveys to develop a profile of farmers’ social and economic status. This 
information will also serve as baseline for performance monitoring. Supervise 
survey data collection by EA and IAs, and verify through spot-checks in at least 
three counties. 
(iii)   Conduct, based on the Initial Poverty and Social Assessment (Appendix 2), a 
social analysis in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Social Analysis (footnote 
4). Assess how the proposed Project will help improve farmers’ incomes and 
livelihoods. In collaboration with the forestry economists, estimate (a) the number 
of project beneficiaries by area, occupation, and income level (poor, low, medium, 
and high); and (b) the number of adversely affected people by type of impact. 
Recommend  measures  to  enhance  benefits,  minimize  adverse  impacts,  and 
improve livelihoods, particularly for the poor. 
(iv)   Assess other social issues including those related to gender and vulnerable 
groups, and recommend appropriate measures to address impacts and promote 
development opportunities during various stages of the Project. Appraise more 
in-depth  the  actual  presence  or  absence  of  indigenous  peoples  (IP)  among 
affected people, and the likelihood of involuntary resettlement (IR) during project 
implementation.  Revise  IP  and  IR  categorizations  accordingly  and  plan 
preparation of IP and IR plans, if needed.   
(v)   Carry out a detailed gender assessment of the project area using ADB’s Gender 
Checklist: Agriculture as reference and analyze vulnerabilities linked to gender 
issues. Develop a social and/or gender action plan and discuss the draft plan

Appendix 4     17 
with EA and IAs, relevant chapters of the women’s federation, and the poverty 
and/or social affairs bureaus.   
(vi)   Identify stakeholders including beneficiaries at village level and representatives 
to be consulted to incorporate their needs and demands into the Project. Prepare 
a  public  participation  and  consultation  status  report  and  plan  for  project 
implementation. This consultation plan could be combined with the environmental 
and resettlement aspects. 
(vii)   Review local government policies, strategies, and programs for poverty reduction 
and regional economic development as these pertain to the project area. Analyze 
how  the  proposed  sustainable  forest  ecosystem  development  project  will 
complement government development programs. Consult with local governments 
to identify development initiatives that could complement the Project, particularly 
those targeted at the poor and ethnic minorities; and identify possible sources of 
funding for these initiatives. 
(viii)  Develop, together with the economists, a set of verifiable and easily monitored 
socioeconomic and poverty indicators. Specify baseline targets and assist with 
the preparation of the performance monitoring and evaluation systems including 
a  reporting  format  and  how  to  measure  indicators  during  and  beyond  the 
plantation stage. 
 
6.  Forest Plantation Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
11.  The consultant shall conduct the following tasks and other activities that are reasonably 
required to prepare procurement and financing plans in line with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time): 
(i)    Review current forest plantation development methods and tree species in the 
project area and suggest appropriate tree species and plantation modalities in 
meeting the project objectives. 
(ii)  Design a plantation implementation plan, prepare procurement packages, and 
suggest procurement modes based on ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (footnote 
10). Design bidding documents for project implementation.  
(iii)   Prepare implementation arrangements and a terms of reference for consulting 
services for supervising project implementation. 
(iv)  Review the current status of forestry trade centers and information centers in the 
project  area  including  their  facilities,  maintenance,  and  management 
arrangements. Assess the opportunity of and recommend actions to foster their 
functions and services to the private sector. 
 
7.  GIS Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
12.   The GIS specialist’s tasks will include, but not limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)    Review the existing GIS established in several participating counties, such as 
Xuichuan  County,  and  identify  and  draw  lessons  on  its  strengths  and 
weaknesses. 
(ii)   Develop a selection criteria to identify two counties wherein a GIS will be set up 
in each of the two counties. 
(iii)   Suggest proper hardware and software for GIS and procure necessary soft and 
hardwares after EA’s and ADB’s approval. 
(iv)   Set up GIS including an information inquiry system and a spatial data processing 
system, and demonstrate data capture and quality control. Carry out training on

18     Appendix 4 
 
the use of GIS in forest resources management and transfer the systems to the 
two counties. 
 
8.  Agricultural Insurance Specialists (international, 3 person-months; national, 3 
  person-months) 
 
13.  The consultants will work together with the national forestry economist to assess the 
options  of  introducing  and  designing  an  agricultural  insurance  mechanism  in  the  Project. 
Specifically, they will:  
(i)  Coordinate with the agricultural insurance specialists working on TA7027-PRC: 
Strengthening the Capacity of Sanmenxia Municipality Government in Strategic 
Planning and Management, and review international practices and products on 
agriculture insurance. 
(ii)  Review domestic insurance regulations and legislative procedures for agriculture 
insurance as well as existing practices and designs in the PRC and the Jiangxi 
Province on agriculture insurance; and summarize the experiences and lessons 
learned  including  discussions  with  the  insurance  industry,  governments,  and 
farmers associations and/or groups. 
(iii)  Analyze the legislative and institutional feasibility for agriculture insurance in the 
project area and provide policy recommendations. 
(iv)  Assess participating enterprises’ and farmers’ affordability and willingness to pay 
for  the  proposed  agricultural  insurance  (a)  conducting  necessary  surveys 
including developing the survey framework (e.g., stratification, randomization, 
etc.) and questionnaire; (b) managing the survey progress; (c) analyzing the data; 
and (d) assessing the affordability and desirability toward the proposed insurance 
mechanisms from the participating enterprises’ and farmers’ perspectives.  
(v)  Prepare a set of designs for agriculture insurance in the project area in close 
consultation with insurance industry, the local governments, and the participating 
enterprises and farmers. 
(vi)  Assess  these  design  options  in  terms  of  their  feasibility,  sustainability,  and 
practicality  given  the  local  institutional  setup;  and  estimate  the  costs  of  the 
insurance industry’s providing and managing agriculture insurance of different 
designs in the project area. 
(vii)  Provide recommendations to and assist EA to pilot-test the design in the project 
area. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
 
14.  The Consultant team leader, in collaboration with the team members, will deliver the 
following reports: (i) an inception report within 1 month of commencement of the TA, (ii) an 
interim report to be submitted in the 4th month, (iii) a draft final report and the knowledge product 
to be submitted in the 6th month, and (iv) a final report to be submitted at the conclusion of the 
TA. The consultants will submit all reports in English and Chinese languages—three copies 
each to the Government and three copies of the English version to ADB including one electronic 
copy on a compact disc. 
 
15.  The draft final report will be structured in accordance with ADB’s format for the report 
and recommendation of the President and will cover each chapter with sufficient supplementary 
reports and environmental and social safeguard documents for ADB to prepare its internal 
report. The final report will reflect comments made by government agencies, ADB, and other 
stakeholders.
